scenarioDescription:
The GJ 687 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 687 is a star with 0.4 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.42 times its radius. It is located 14.84 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 687 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 687 system


GJ 687 b

GJ 687 b was discovered by the Lick Observatory observatory, in 2014-07, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 687 b is 17.210 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 687 b is 4.320 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 687 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 687 c

GJ 687 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2020-08, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 687 c is 16.008 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 687 c is 4.140 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 687 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 687, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Lick Observatory.
name: GJ 687 - System With 2 Exoplanets
